passages.text: Technology | IT Hardware & Networking

ALL YOU NEED TO KNOW: During Day 2 of our Semiconductor, IT Hardware & Networking Conference, we had the opportunity to meet with several companies across the IT Hardware, Networking, and Industrial Tech landscape (CDW, EXTR, MSI, TTMI, WDC, and more). Some of the key overarching themes that we heard from companies were consistent were what we heard on day 1 (strong cloud/DC and A&D end demand trends, mixed auto, customer buying behavior normalizing despite tariff uncertainty, importance of HDD, etc.). Themes we heard from day 2 include: 1) Uneven Federal/Public Sector Spending Backdrop: Defense/public safety related spending remains strong though spending in civilian agencies has been weaker. 2) PC Market Strength Driven by Windows 11 Upgrades: Device refresh related to Windows 11 has been a driver of PC market strength and AI PCs could extend the cycle for longer. 3) Enterprise IT Spending Remains Positive with broad- based growth across product categories while SMB spending is more targeted (cloud, devices). 4) Spending on networking should grow as the industry transitions past inventory digestion.
\*\*\*For detailed notes from our discussions or our run- down on the most positive meetings, please contact us\*\*\*

CDW- Prudent FY25 Guide; Multiple Upside Levers Ahead: We met with Al Miralles (CFO), Steven O'Brien (VP of IR), and Dan Cartwright. Management characterized growth in the last quarter as broadly balanced, with durable performance in networking and storage and server demand concentrated in large enterprises. Client devices delivered a sixth consecutive quarter of growth, driven primarily by the Windows 11 refresh rather than AI PCs—though management noted there is more room for growth with elevated ASPs as TTM PC revenue is \(\sim\) 6.7B versus a \(\) 8.2B\(peak. SMB spending remains resilient but focused on devices and cloud, while corporate demand is broader across solutions and services. Federal remains uneven with strength in Defense while Civilian is weaker. Gross margin for the full year is expected to hold in the \~22% range (street at 21.6%) while full- year FCF conversion is targeted at 80–90%. In terms of capital allocation, the company is focusing on services- led M&A and opportunistic buybacks within balance- sheet discipline.

MSI - Strong Product Orders Momentum, Silvus TAM Expansion, Public Safety Prioritization: We met with Tim Yocum (VP of IR) and Vicki Tzolov (Director of IR). During our meeting, MSI discussed the drivers of product orders growth momentum in H2 (LMR device refresh, base station refresh, fixed video, and Silvus), multi- year LMR network refresh opportunity (potential to upsell software/services during sales process), attractive TAM expansion provided by Silvus (entry into defense and fast growing drone opportunity), medium- term OBBBA tailwinds, and attractive video markets dynamics. Despite concerns surrounding scrutiny of government spend, public safety remains a key priority and budgets related to this should remain positive.

WDC- Favorable Dynamics Stacking Up: We met with Ambrish Srivastava (VP, IR) and Amitesh Bajad (Director, IR). The company noted that visibility has improved with LTAs now in place with all top five hyperscalers into H1:26 (two extending into FY27). Notably,

the HDD market is structurally different from previous cycles and showing better pricing than the \(- 7\%\) ASP base case decline outlined at their Investor Day. Not only has capacity tightened ( \(\sim 50M\) units vs. \(\sim 80M\) during the peak), but the market is also shifting to EB- based terms. WDC also provided an update on HAMR, and that areal density development is ahead of plan. Though it's worth noting, that the company is also expanding their UltraSMR products - which provides \(\sim 20\%\) capacity uplift at no incremental cost. WDC expects UltraSMR to make up \(\sim 50\%\) of nearline by end- CY25, which should be margin accretive- though there may be some variability sequentially due to customer implementation and timing. Longer term, HDD growth is expected to remain favorable as they remain essential for cloud storage \(\sim 85\%\) of data) alongside SSDs in tiered AI/inferencing architectures. On the balance sheet and cash flow side, WDC intends to sell its remaining SanDisk shares by February as it delivers toward \(1 - 1.5x\) net leverage and return \(100\%\) of excess cash over time.

EXTR - Transition Past Inventory Digestion: We had the opportunity to meet with Stan Kovler (SVP of IR and Corporate Development) from Extreme Networks (EXTR). The company was focused on several key trends that are benefiting them - 1) Networking growth ahead - EXTR noted they are done with the inventory digestion and are starting to see spending resume and buying pattern normalization is starting to happen across multiple verticals, 2) Share gain opportunity - EXTR should see tailwinds not just from a better demand environment but also potential for share gains. 3) Platform One - EXTR is shifting towards an AI driven unified platform for customers that should help drive a stickier ecosystem and help drive a higher subscription revenue growth. 4) Margin framework: EXTR expects margins to improve from low/mid teens to \(20\% +\) over time driven by a host of tailwinds.

TTMI - End Market Strength and Path Toward Further Margin Improvement: We met with Dan Boehle (CFO) and Sameer Desai (VP of Corp Dev and IR). During our meeting, TTMI highlighted strong underlying fundamentals within their top end market verticals (Aerospace & Defense and Data Center) with growth attributed to higher defense spending budgets within A&D and AI within Data Centers. More recently, the company has improved their EBIT margin profile toward the lower end of their \(11 - 13\%\) target margin profile (Q2 margin was up \(+210\) bps y/y) while the company has a clear path to margin expansion as utilization of their Penang facility increases.
We had the opportunity to meet with Al Miralles (CFO), Steven O'Brien (VP of IR), and Dan Cartwright from CDW. Key topics from meetings were as follows:

Client- Devices Strengthened Upside: Performance in the latest quarter was strong across all- end markets with the exception of education and federal, marking six consecutive quarters of growth. Management noted that strength largely came from Windows 11 refresh over the rather than AI PCs, which may provide some "extra innings" though most of the near- term growth today remains tied to Windows 11. Current TTM PC sales are \(\sim\) 6.7B compared to a peak of \(\sim\) 8.2B in Q2:22 which suggests room for further upside, particularly as ASPs are higher than historically. It's also worth noting that pandemic- era devices will soon be five years old, which should drive a normal replacement cycle in CY26.

SMB vs. Corporate: Management noted that SMB spending has been resilient but concentrated mainly in client devices and cloud. On the other hand, corporate demand has been broader with investments spread across solutions and services. Additionally, SMB refresh needs are tied closely to cloud and device lifecycles.

PC Market and Share Gains: CDW expects commercial PCs to solidify outperform the broader market. Notably, the company is seeing broad- based share gains, with management emphasizing that this segment is CDW's sweet spot. Growth has not been tied to taking sales from partners but rather expansion of the overall pie.

Gross Margins: Gross margins rose in the previous quarter due to mix shift toward higher- quality products and management expects margins to remain consistent with CY24 ( \(\sim 22\%\) ). Netted- down revenues will likely continue to outperform overall growth but vary quarter to quarter. Software and SaaS growth are adding mix benefits without dilution from AI yet. Overall, margins are expected to stay resilient across customer cohorts.

Infrastructure and Storage Strength: Networking and storage remain durable categories with broad- based growth. Server demand for the company has been concentrated in large enterprises while other channels have yet to show the same breadth of server demand—and management indicated hopes of stronger and broader demand across customers in the coming quarters.

Tariffs and Spending Normalization: Tariff uncertainty has largely normalized in Q2- although CDW did note some pull- forward in Q1 ( \(\sim\) 100M in pull- forward PC). The company noted that customers are now making calmer investment decisions. Specifically, conversations on spend were more dramatic early in the year but have since stabilized.

Federal Demand Remains Choppy: While State and Local remain steady, federal spending patterns remain choppy - especially in civilian agencies which is based on headcount. Defense demand, however, has been more stable. CDW expects federal friction to persist through H2, though there could be some upside if stabilization comes sooner. In the long term, DOGE efficiency needs should support more technology spending and management remains confident in being a partner for government customers as dynamics normalize.

Education Uncertainty: K- 12 spending has been uneven following the expiration of pandemic stimulus. While refresh needs are evident (coming up on 5 years), budgets are constrained by funding tied to grants and other programs which have been paused under the current administration. Although, management did note that some funding for teacher development and childcare has recently been upheld. Despite this, CDW remains cautious in the near term and is pushing back expectations of a pick- up to CY26.

M&A in Networking: Industry consolidation in networking is seen as a net positive for CDW. During transition periods, CDW's relationships make it a trusted partner and the company does not expect disruption but rather stronger positioning.

Solutions and Enterprise Outlook: Solutions and enterprise showed outsized growth in Q2. However, H2 guidance assumes moderation and does not expect similar strength to persist. Federal and education are not assumed to rebound in the near term. Enterprise demand is expected to normalize at a steady pace. Management is intentionally cautious in projecting growth.

Software and AI: While CDW is noting AI interest is present, it is not yet a major revenue driver. Notably, the company is the largest reseller of Microsoft Copilot but have not yet seen large contribution of AI- infused software.

Free Cash Flow: Free cash flow is expected at \(80 - 90\%\) conversion for the full year. Management noted that the first half of the year was more pressured due to inventory and working capital timing, but management is confident in H2 ability to generate cash flow.

Operating Leverage Expectations: While operating leverage was significant in Q1, CDW expects some moderation through the year. Specifically, the company expects CY25 to be a transition year and is actively reducing its cost base to support leverage—expecting CY26 to normalize more.

PC Pull- Forward: CDW estimates that there was \(\sim \$ 100M\) in pull- forward in Q1 but noted little indication of pull- in in Q2. Specifically, their PC business is now more diversified across Chrome, iOS, and Windows, and ASPs remain healthy with customers seeking larger screens and faster memory.

Capital Allocation Priorities: Capital allocation priorities include dividends, selective M&A, and opportunistic buybacks. For M&A, the company is focused on companies with serviced capital capabilities (ex. MissionCloud). They also remain opportunistic on buybacks depending on market conditions and there will be periods when they see more M&A opportunity, which means they may be underweight buybacks, but that is not the case this year as they view buybacks as more opportunistic in nature. Management will not over- lever for repurchases but will scale up opportunistically.

Customer Conversations and AI: CDW emphasized that they are engaged in nearly all areas of technology including AI. However, when it comes to spend, customers are currently prioritizing "must have" refreshes before discretionary wants. Specifically for AI deployments, ROI benefits are the most important consideration – with both IT and business units involved in decisions.
We had the opportunity to meet with Tim Yocum (VP of IR) and Vicki Tzolov (Director of IR) at MSI. Key topics from meetings were as follows:

Product Orders Growth Momentum Should Continue in H2: During Q2, MSI product orders grew \(+10\%\) y/y – management expects momentum to sustain for the balance of CY25 (strong funnel) driven by LMR device refresh, infrastructure refresh, and fixed video (Silvus should contribute to product orders growth as well).

Solid Demand Backdrop: MSI indicated that orders and demand have been consistent and they do not expect fluctuations in demand (despite concerns surrounding scrutiny of government spend, public safety remains a key priority). For CY25, orders should be up y/y and they see a strong funnel related to APX NEXT and network infrastructure as they look into CY26. Although the pandemic and associated supply chain shocks did have an impact on buying behavior, component availability has since normalized and backlog has returned to normal levels. Over \(90\%\) of MSI's \(14.1B\) in backlog (at Q2 end) is with government/public safety customers (orders are not cancellable).

Network Infrastructure Refresh Opportunity with New D- Series Base Stations: MSI recently introduced their new D- Series LMR base station (first base station product in 12 years). The new LMR infrastructure product features improved energy efficiency, more robust cybersecurity, remote software upgrades, and greater interoperability using low orbit satellites. So far, the company has disclosed initial orders from St. Louis, Michigan, and Chicago among other cities. D- Series should contribute to orders performance while providing multi- year tailwinds. As customers upgrade their base stations, it also provides MSI with an opportunity to upsell additional software and services.

Silvus an Entry Point for More Defense Deals/Business? While management did not disclose whether their recent acquisition of Silvus will enable the company to expand into the large (and relatively unpenetrated) defense opportunity, they indicated that further expansion into this vertical seems logical given the company's history of expanding into other adjacent markets (Video, Command Center, etc.). Although Silvus primarily serves the defense market, the company views the target as an adjacent technology (RF engineering, radio- type communications). Silvus provides MSI with an entry into the unmanned opportunity ("a couple billion" dollar TAM that's growing exponentially to several billion over the next few years).

Silvus Accretion Timeline: Silvus should be \(\sim \$ 0.20\) accretive next year and will look to pay down debt to finance the acquisition in the next 12- 18 months (reduce net leverage to under \(\sim 2x\) ). The company does not expect to do another Silvus- sized transaction ( \(\sim \$ 4.4B\) ) while they are integrating the asset.

LMR Provides Mission Critical Communications + Control: Management does not expect technologies such as 5G/6G etc. to displace LMR communications. They highlighted the importance of LMR (better coverage, uptime, capacity, and priority vs. cellular for mission critical communications). LMR also allows customers to own their own networks which provides them with more control vs. relying on other networks. Although MSI customers own their own LMR networks, the company does monetize/make use of existing LTE infrastructure by integrating other capabilities (LTE, apps) onto LMR devices (APX NEXT devices average annual \(\) 300\(per year of software spend per device from apps).

Attractive Video Opportunity: MSI noted that they generate \(\sim \$ 2B\) in revenue within a \(\sim \$ 37B\) TAM for video. The company is investing in innovation (AI within management software such as search, AI at device level, cloud- enabled, etc.). The mix shift toward cloud video should improve revenue visibility.

OBBBA Passing Should Provide Tailwinds: Increased defense/border security spending related to OBBBA should provide MSI with tailwinds (over four years) within their LMR and video businesses. Although it is too early to quantify benefits of this bill, management noted that they could see orders related to OBBBA as early as Q4 of this year. Within LMR, MSI sees potential for increased spending to result in demand for more LMR devices, body- worn cameras, and live translation capabilities offered on their new SVX body- worn AI assistant (SVX can address both BWC and live translation needs).

M&A Strategy: MSI will focus on inorganic growth opportunities within Video and Command Center technologies. On the LMR side, they prefer to organically invest/innovate (LTE- enabled APX NEXT devices are an example of this). The company is mindful of valuations and potential dilutive impacts of larger deals; they highlighted the importance of driving accretion out of larger acquisitions quickly as in the case of the Silvus acquisition.
We had the opportunity to meet with Ambrish Srivastava (VP, IR) and Amitesh Bajad (Director, IR) from WDC. Key topics from meetings were as follows:

Visibility and BTO Demand: Management indicated that they now have LTAs extending into H1:26 with the top five hyperscalers, and most recently two of them extending their commitments further into FY27.

\\$/EB Market Framework: The HDD market remains a three- player structure, with more stable pricing vs. SSDs. WDC reiterated their investor day framework with the base case assumption of a \(7\%\) ASP decline, though pricing has been better than expected over the last six to eight quarters, trending flat to slightly down.

HAMR Development: While the HAMR technology is complex, WDC has been making progress, with complementary development of eMPR. Specifically, development of HAMR is progressing well, with areal density already ahead of internal goals. Two of their largest customers are stress- testing drives in demanding environments, with positive commentary so far. Notably, the company's capex target of \(4 - 6\%\) includes HAMR investments and management noted that much of the PMR toolset is reusable for HAMR.

TCO with HAMR and SMR: UltraSMR provides WDC's customers with \(20\%\) uplift at no incremental cost, compared to \(10\%\) for standard SMR. This technological advantage is translatable to HAMR, which can be integrated with both CMR and UltraSMR. Management expects UltraSMR to be margin accretive and projects the technology to account for \(50\%\) of nearline mix by the end of CY25.

Industry Structure Compared to Past Cycles: While there are concerns on the cyclical nature of the industry, management noted structural differences in the market. Capacity has been reduced from \(\sim 80M\) units previously (FY22) to \(\sim 50M\) today and the industry is shifting away from unit- based contracts toward EB- based agreements. WDC also emphasized that they will no longer expand capacity through increasing units, but rather areal density improvements—focusing only on heads and media.

Flash, SSD, and HDD Dynamics: WDC noted that HDDs remain essential for cloud storage, with \(85\%\) of data stored on HDDs, even though SSDs are growing faster. Specifically, management believes the two can co- exist and are complementary in a tiered architecture. The company emphasized that HDDs continue to hold a TCO advantage, even in AI and inferencing workloads where retraining models requires HDD capacity.

Ultra SMR Adoption: Nearline adoption of Ultra SMR has averaged \(40 - 45\%\) and is expected to reach \(50\%\) by the end of CY25. Currently, two customers are in volume production, a third just completed qualification, and a fourth is undergoing qualification. WDC also noted that while the technology is accretive to margins, there may be some sequential variability due to renewal timing and that customer adoption will not be linear.

Capacity Levels and Drive Roadmap: The company's mass capacity average capacity/ drive is 18- 19TB while their competitor is at 16.5TB. Notably, the company's roadmap to higher density drives is more gradual—emphasizing a low- risk transition. Specifically, WDC is targeting capacity transition points of 26- 32TB, 28- 36TB, and 36- 44TB.

Operating Expense: Operating expense is expected to be higher by \(\sim \$ 15M\) due to an extra week in the Sept- qtr. For the remainder of the year, expenses are expected to be normalize to previous quarter levels as the company continues focusing investment in eMPR and HAMR.

Sandisk: As communicated at Investor Day, management intends to dispose of remaining shares of Sandisk ( \(\sim 7.5M\) shares) by February. The sale of the retained stake is part of the company's broader deleveraging strategy going forward.
Net Leverage and Free Cash Flow: Longer- term, the company is targeting net leverage of 1- 1.5x, providing flexibility to return \(100\%\) of excess cash to shareholders.
Supply Chain: WDC's supply chain is largely vertically integrated with drive heads primarily produced in San Jose and Fremont. Media production is also mostly internal, and the

company is exploring in- house laser manufacturing. WDC noted that they also have experience with glass media – which they use for consumer drives—and has established supply chain resilience across multiple vendors.
Seasonality: Only about \(10\%\) of the business is exposed to seasonal fluctuations as \(90\%\) of WDC's business is now cloud.
We had the opportunity to meet with Stan Kovler (SVP of IR and Corporate Development) from EXTR. Key topics from meetings were as follows:

Acceleration in H2: EXTR was incrementally confident on their ability to see growth accelerate in H2 driven by a combination of easier compares, inventory digestion being done and better demand trends as customers refresh their campus solutions.
Inventory Digestion: EXTR is done working through Wi- Fi 6 inventory. Starting to ramp up for Wi- Fi 7. \(\sim 30\%\) of sales are Wi- Fi 7 driven.
Share Gain Opportunity: EXTR should see tailwinds not just from a better demand environment but also potential for share gains. The biggest opportunity is vs. CSCO, and secondarily vs. HPE/JNPR.

Channel Tailwinds: Multiple peers are trying to change their channel incentive programs that should help drive better tailwinds for EXTR. For example, Cisco is trying to merge their channel program to merge networking and security. While larger VARs are excited about this, smaller vendors will have an issue on this. As you move down the channel pyramid – vendors that just want to do networking (not doing security) they lose points/rebates in this new model – they could look at EXTR.
HPE/JNPR – Dynamics: HPE is also looking to do some extent of channel realignment. JNPR channel partners tends to be smaller partners, they could be ripe for incr. wins from EXTR's perspective.
HPE Education Vertical: EXTR is seeing better traction on the education vertical, where the gains are notable vs. HPE.

Extreme Platform ONE – Al- Driven Unified Platform. Key features – 1) Unified AI Powered Management: Combines networking, security, and orchestration. Reduces manual tasks by \(\sim 90\%\) , streamlining operations across wired, wireless, and edge environments 2) Expanded Hardware Integration: Wi- Fi 7 Access Points: Broad lineup for both indoor and outdoor high- performance deployments. Campus Core Switches: High- density 100G & 400G models like the 7830; compact 5320 for quiet, space- limited environments; 5120 for IoT. Enhanced Network Visualization: Features like geo maps, overlays, path tracing offer granular insight into fabric behavior. Customizable UI and improved support for troubleshooting.
EBIT Margins – Currently they are around low/mid teens. Should get this to \(20\%\) . Path to margin expansion is sales growth across both product and subscription sales to grow.
We had the opportunity to meet with Dan Boehle (CFO) and Sameer Desai (VP of Corp Dev and IR) from TTMI. Key topics from meetings were as follows:

Levered to Growth Markets: Aerospace & Defense (A&D) and Data Center Computing + Networking combined account for \(\sim 80\%\) of total revenue and these end market verticals have seen solid/strong end market fundamentals.

Defense Tailwinds: TTMI expects the A&D end market ( \(\sim 50\%\) of total revenue) to grow mid single- digits; within this end market, TTMI is benefiting from broader defense spending (aircraft radar replacement). Longer term, emerging opportunities such as unmanned could contribute to growth.

AI Driving Data Center Computing + Networking Headwinds: These two end markets combined, account for \(\sim 30\%\) of total revenue and growth has been driven by AI infrastructure ramps. TTMI sells PBC products into servers and switches used for AI workloads.

Strong EBIT Margin Performance With Path to Further Expansion: Since TTMI's divesture of China manufacturing (more consumer electronics focused) in 2020, they have steadily expanded their margin profile. During TTMI's most recent quarter, operating margin was \(11.1\%\) , which was up \(+210\) bps y/y, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of double- digit margins. Performance was toward the lower end of their \(11 - 13\%\) target due to the 200bps drag from underutilization of their new Penang facility. Once they achieve breakeven on the new facility, consolidated operating margin could reach the high end of their target margin range (profitability in the Penang site would drive further upside vs. margin targets).

Capex Requirements: TTMI's capex typically accounts for \(4 - 5\%\) of revenue though capex be higher during periods where they are building new facilities. More recently, TTMI is spending to ramp up their Penang and Syracuse facilities.

Revenue Visibility: For A&D, \(80\%\) of annual revenue in any given year is driven by backlog. However for their AI data center business, visibility is lower here ( \(80\%\) of revenue in a quarter backlog driven). Lead times typically trend in the \(\sim 3\) month range.

Book- to- Bill Trends: Book- to- bill for Q2 was 0.89 with commercial at 1.07x and A&D at 0.69. Book- to- bill within A&D tends to be lumpy (attributable to order timing and not due to demand). Long- term, book- to- bill should be closer to \(\sim 1.0x\) .

Positioned for Onshoring/Reshoring: TTMI recently acquired a 750k sq ft facility in Eau Claire, WI which provides the company with capacity to support future high volume U.S. production of advanced technologies.

Tariff Impact: For A&D and Data Center (which combine for \(\sim 80\%\) of total revenue), these businesses have seen limited tariff impact (these markets have their own investment cycle unrelated to tariffs). Auto ( \(\sim 10\%\) of revenue) did experience a moderate level of tariff- related pull- in.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR)
Time of dissemination: August 28 2025 6:45 AM ET

Evercore ISI's recommendations are based on a stock's total forecasted return over the next 12 months. Total forecasted return is equal to the expected percentage price return plus gross dividend yield. We divide our stocks under coverage into three primary ratings categories, with the following return guidelines:
Outperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be greater than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.
In Line- the total forecasted return is expected to be in line with the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.
Underperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be less than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.

Coverage Suspended- the rating and target price have been removed pursuant to Evercore ISI policy when Evercore is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving this company and in certain other circumstances.

Rating Suspended- Evercore ISI has suspended the rating and target price for this stock because there is not sufficient fundamental basis for determining, or there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints around publishing, a rating or target price. The previous rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this company and should not be relied upon.
Prior to October 10, 2015, the "Coverage Suspended" and "Rating Suspended" categories were included in the category "Suspended."

FINRA requires that members who use a ratings system with terms other than "Buy," "Hold/Neutral" and "Sell" to equate their own ratings to these categories. For this purpose, and in the Evercore ISI ratings distribution below, our Outperform, In Line, and Underperform ratings can be equated to Buy, Hold and Sell, respectively.
